overview.brief_description: Lyon, France's third-largest city and the gastronomic capital of the world, is a UNESCO World Heritage site where Roman ruins, Renaissance architecture, and modern innovation converge. With its iconic Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière, the historic Vieux Lyon quarter, and its legendary culinary scene featuring traditional bouchons and the famous Les Halles de Lyon market, Lyon offers visitors an authentic taste of French culture, history, and gastronomy.
overview.nickname: The Gastronomic Capital of the World

sections.title: Gastronomic Heritage
sections.content: Lyon's unique character is defined by its world-famous culinary scene, with the city serving as the historic center of French gastronomy. The legendary bouchons, traditional Lyonnais restaurants, and the famous Les Halles de Lyon market create a striking urban identity that showcases the city's importance as a center of culinary excellence and the birthplace of many French culinary traditions.

sections.title: Roman and Renaissance Legacy
sections.content: The city's rich history spans from Roman times through the Renaissance, preserved in landmarks like the ancient Théâtre Romain de Fourvière, the magnificent Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière, and the historic Vieux Lyon quarter. These structures tell the story of Lyon's importance as a religious, cultural, and commercial center through the centuries.

sections.title: Silk Industry Heritage
sections.content: Lyon is globally recognized as the historic center of the French silk industry, which has shaped the city's modern identity. The city's cultural heritage continues to drive innovation, while Lyon has evolved into a center for technology, biotechnology, and university culture, balancing traditional heritage with contemporary excellence.

sections.title: Lyonnais Culture
sections.content: Lyon embodies the warm hospitality and rich traditions of the Lyonnais people. Visitors experience this through traditional Lyonnais cuisine featuring local specialties like quenelles, saucisson de Lyon, and local wines, the lively atmosphere of local markets, and the genuine friendliness of residents who are proud to share their city's unique story.

why_visit.intro: Lyon offers visitors a unique opportunity to experience a French city that combines Roman and Renaissance heritage with world-famous gastronomy and Lyonnais culture, featuring authentic local traditions, fascinating history, and a distinctive architectural character that's unlike anywhere else in France.

highlights.title: Historic Architecture
highlights.content: Lyon's distinctive Roman, medieval, and Renaissance architecture creates a unique urban landscape that's become the city's signature feature. The historic buildings, city views, and elegant structures transform ordinary streets into striking architectural statements, making every street corner a potential photo opportunity and creating a magical atmosphere throughout the city.

highlights.title: Place Bellecour
highlights.content: The heart of Lyon, this magnificent square is surrounded by important landmarks including the historic center, the Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière, and beautiful Renaissance architecture. It's the perfect starting point for exploring the city and experiencing the daily life of Lyon's residents.

highlights.title: Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière
highlights.content: This magnificent basilica, located on the Fourvière hill, offers spectacular architecture and insights into the city's religious heritage with its stunning design and cultural significance. The basilica's design represents the pinnacle of 19th-century religious architecture.

highlights.title: Vieux Lyon
highlights.content: Lyon's Renaissance center offers authentic local experiences where visitors can explore narrow cobblestone streets, discover hidden traboules (passageways), and admire the distinctive Renaissance architecture. The area is particularly atmospheric in the evening when the historic buildings take on a magical quality against the city backdrop.

highlights.title: Les Halles de Lyon
highlights.content: In the center of the city, the iconic food market offers spectacular insights into Lyon's culinary heritage and the surrounding Rhône-Alpes landscape. Accessible by walking, it provides a unique perspective on the city's cultural importance and opportunities for culinary appreciation in a historic setting.

highlights.title: Gastronomic Heritage
highlights.content: The city's cultural heritage is celebrated through its restaurants, markets, and traditional crafts, with the famous bouchons offering insights into the region's culinary history and the famous Lyonnais cuisine adding a unique dimension to the city's cultural landscape.

transport.public_transport: Lyon has an efficient metro, tram, and bus system that serves the city and surrounding areas. Taxis are readily available and the city center is compact and walkable, making it easy to explore on foot.
transport.passes: Single tickets and day passes are available for public transport. The city center is easily navigable on foot, with most major attractions within walking distance.

spring.description: Spring brings pleasant temperatures and blooming flowers to Lyon, making it an ideal time to explore the city on foot. The weather is comfortable for outdoor activities, and the surrounding Rhône-Alpes landscape comes to life with seasonal colors.

summer.description: Summer in Lyon is pleasant, with the city's many parks and the nearby Rhône-Alpes countryside providing cool retreats. Evening temperatures are comfortable, making it perfect for enjoying the city's vibrant café culture and outdoor dining scene.

autumn.description: Autumn offers mild temperatures and beautiful fall colors, particularly in the surrounding Rhône-Alpes landscape. The weather is ideal for exploring the city and nearby natural attractions, with fewer crowds than the summer months.

winter.description: Winter in Lyon can be cold and occasionally rainy. The city takes on a cozy atmosphere, with indoor attractions like museums and the historic center providing warm refuge. The nearby Rhône-Alpes countryside offers winter landscape beauty.

sites.name: Place Bellecour
sites.description: This vast open square is one of the largest pedestrian squares in Europe and serves as the central hub of Lyon. Notable for its statue of Louis XIV on horseback and the iconic Ferris wheel in winter, Place Bellecour offers views of Fourvière Hill and connects the Presqu'île district's main shopping streets.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful in spring with blooming flowers. Winter features a Christmas market and Ferris wheel. Summer evenings are lively with locals and tourists.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free public space accessible at all times.

sites.name: Basilique Notre-Dame de Fourvière
sites.description: Perched dramatically on Fourvière Hill overlooking the city, this stunning 19th-century basilica combines Byzantine and Romanesque styles. Its opulent interior features beautiful mosaics, stained glass, and marble work. The terrace provides one of the most spectacular panoramic views of Lyon.
sites.seasonal_notes: Less crowded on weekday mornings. The basilica is beautifully lit at night. December 8th features the spectacular Festival of Lights (Fête des Lumières).
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for the basilica. The adjacent museum has a small entrance fee.

sites.name: Vieux Lyon (Old Town)
sites.description: One of Europe's largest Renaissance districts, Vieux Lyon is characterized by its narrow cobblestone streets, hidden traboules (passageways), Gothic and Renaissance architecture, and vibrant atmosphere. Split into three areas (Saint-Jean, Saint-Paul, and Saint-Georges), it's filled with restaurants, shops, and historical buildings.
sites.seasonal_notes: Early mornings offer quiet exploration opportunities. Extremely busy during summer and weekends. Restaurants are lively in evenings.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for exploring. Guided tours available for discovering hidden traboules and history.

sites.name: Musée des Beaux-Arts
sites.description: Housed in a former 17th-century Benedictine convent, Lyon's Fine Arts Museum is considered the next most important in France after the Louvre. The collection spans antiquity to modern art, featuring works by Monet, Picasso, Rembrandt, Rubens, and ancient Egyptian artifacts.
sites.seasonal_notes: Less crowded on weekdays. Special exhibitions rotate throughout the year. The museum is air-conditioned, making it a perfect refuge on hot summer days.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required for general admission. Guided tours available with museum entry.

sites.name: Parc de la Tête d'Or
sites.description: Lyon's largest urban park covers 117 hectares and features a large lake, botanical garden, rose garden, and a free zoo. Popular with joggers, families, and picnickers, the park offers rowing boats, a miniature train, and beautiful landscaped spaces for relaxation.
sites.seasonal_notes: Spectacular in spring when flowers bloom and in autumn for colorful foliage. The greenhouse tropical collections are perfect for winter visits.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free entry to the park, botanical gardens, and zoo.

sites.name: Les Halles de Lyon Paul Bocuse
sites.description: This prestigious indoor food market named after Lyon's most famous chef features around 50 vendors selling gourmet products. From cheese and charcuterie to chocolates, seafood, and wines, the market showcases the finest regional produce that makes Lyon the gastronomic capital of France.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with seasonal specialties. Busier on weekends. Many stalls close on Mondays and some close for lunch between 2-5 PM.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for browsing. Come hungry to sample products. Several small restaurants within the market require reservations on weekends.

sites.name: Musée des Confluences
sites.description: Located at the confluence of the Rhône and Saône rivers, this striking deconstructivist building houses a science and anthropology museum. Its innovative exhibitions explore big questions about humanity, civilization, and natural history through diverse artifacts ranging from dinosaur fossils to contemporary art.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. The museum terrace offers excellent views of the confluence and is particularly pleasant in summer evenings.
sites.booking_tips: Online booking recommended for weekends and holidays. Free entry first Sunday of each month.

sites.name: Amphithéâtre des Trois Gaules
sites.description: This ancient Roman amphitheater on the slopes of La Croix-Rousse dates from 19 AD and once seated 20,000 spectators. It was where the first Christian martyrs of Gaul were executed in 177 AD, making it an important historical and religious site.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. The site offers little shade, so morning visits are best in summer. Information panels provide historical context.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. The site is freely accessible.

sites.name: Théâtres Romains de Fourvière
sites.description: Adjacent to the Fourvière Basilica, these well-preserved Roman theaters date from the 1st century BC. The Grand Theater could seat 10,000 people, while the smaller Odeon was used for musical performances. Today, the site hosts the popular Nuits de Fourvière festival in summer.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best visited in the morning before heat builds up. The annual Nuits de Fourvière festival runs from June to July with performances in the ancient theater.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for general access. Festival performances require advance tickets.

sites.name: La Croix-Rousse
sites.description: Known as 'the hill that works' (in contrast to Fourvière, 'the hill that prays'), this historic silk workers' district retains its bohemian, village-like atmosphere. Once the center of Lyon's silk industry, its traboules, workshops, and distinctive architecture tell the story of the canuts (silk workers).
sites.seasonal_notes: The Croix-Rousse market on Boulevard de la Croix-Rousse is one of Lyon's best (Tuesday-Sunday mornings). The neighborhood hosts various festivals throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for exploring. Guided tours available focusing on silk-working history and traboules.

sites.name: Musée Lumière
sites.description: Housed in the Art Nouveau villa of the Lumière family, this museum is dedicated to Antoine, Louis, and Auguste Lumière, who invented the cinematograph and created the world's first motion picture in 1895. The museum displays early filming equipment, photographs, and screens historic films.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. The annual Lumière Film Festival in October celebrates heritage cinema and attracts international stars.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Guided tours available in multiple languages.

sites.name: Institut & Musée Lumière
sites.description: Located in the historic Lumière factory, this museum celebrates the Lumière brothers who invented cinema. The exhibits showcase their technical innovations through original equipment, films, and personal effects, telling the story of early cinematography in the very place where the first film was shot.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. The museum hosts the annual Lumière Festival in October, a major event in heritage cinema.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Guided tours available with additional insights.

sites.name: Murs des Canuts
sites.description: Located in the Croix-Rousse district, this is the largest trompe-l'œil fresco in Europe at 1,200 square meters. It depicts the history and daily life of Lyon's silk workers (canuts) with remarkable realism, creating an optical illusion that blends into the neighborhood.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best viewed in morning light. The mural has been updated several times, with changes reflecting the evolution of the neighborhood.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free to view at any time.

sites.name: Cathédrale Saint-Jean-Baptiste
sites.description: This magnificent Gothic cathedral in the heart of Vieux Lyon was built between the 12th and 15th centuries. Known for its 14th-century astronomical clock, beautiful stained glass, and blend of Romanesque and Gothic architecture, it serves as the primary cathedral of Lyon.
sites.seasonal_notes: The astronomical clock performs daily at 12, 2, 3, and 4 PM. The cathedral hosts special services during Easter and Christmas.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Respect quiet during services. Small donation for viewing the astronomical clock.

sites.name: Musée Gadagne
sites.description: Housed in a Renaissance mansion in the heart of Vieux Lyon, this complex contains two museums: the Lyon History Museum and the International Puppet Museum. Its rooftop garden café offers charming views over the old town's rooftops.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. The courtyard and gardens are particularly pleasant in spring and summer.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Combined ticket for both museums offers best value.

sites.name: Musée d'Art Contemporain
sites.description: Located in the Cité Internationale complex designed by Renzo Piano, this contemporary art museum features temporary exhibitions of current trends in modern art. The museum is known for its innovative programming and commitment to emerging artists.
sites.seasonal_notes: The museum sometimes closes between exhibitions. Check the schedule before visiting. The surrounding park is pleasant for walks in good weather.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Check the website for current exhibitions as the museum focuses on temporary shows.

sites.name: Berges du Rhône
sites.description: This 5km landscaped promenade along the eastern bank of the Rhône River has transformed former parking lots into a vibrant public space. Popular for jogging, cycling, and relaxing, it features floating restaurants (péniches), gardens, playgrounds, and sports facilities.
sites.seasonal_notes: Extremely popular in summer when locals gather to picnic and socialize. Many outdoor events and pop-up activities during warm months.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Bike rentals available nearby with city bike scheme.

sites.name: Musée Miniature et Cinéma
sites.description: Located in a 16th-century building in Vieux Lyon, this unique museum combines incredible miniature scenes created with painstaking detail by artist Dan Ohlmann with an exhibition of original movie props, costumes, and special effects elements from major films.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. A good rainy day activity. Can be busy during school holidays.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Allow plenty of time to appreciate the incredible detail in the miniatures.

sites.name: Place des Terreaux
sites.description: This historic square is bordered by the Lyon City Hall and the Museum of Fine Arts. Its centerpiece is the famous Bartholdi fountain, originally designed for the city of Bordeaux. The square hosts cafés with outdoor seating and is beautifully illuminated at night.
sites.seasonal_notes: Lively throughout the year. Spectacular during the Festival of Lights in December. Summer evenings feature outdoor dining.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. The square is always accessible.

sites.name: Fresque des Lyonnais
sites.description: This remarkable trompe-l'œil mural covers 800 square meters and depicts 30 famous historical and contemporary figures from Lyon, including the Lumière brothers, Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, and Paul Bocuse. The hyper-realistic style creates a striking optical illusion.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best photographed in morning light. The mural can be viewed year-round.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free to view at any time.

sites.name: Bouchons Lyonnais
sites.description: These traditional Lyon restaurants serve authentic local cuisine in a warm, convivial atmosphere. Dishes typically include quenelles (pike dumplings), andouillette (tripe sausage), and various pork specialties. The name 'bouchon' comes from the small twisted straw brushes used to clean horses outside these establishments.
sites.seasonal_notes: Many traditional dishes are hearty and best enjoyed in cooler months. Authentic bouchons display the official certification label.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking recommended, especially for dinner and weekends. Look for the official 'Authentique Bouchon Lyonnais' certification.

neighborhoods.name: Vieux Lyon
neighborhoods.character: A UNESCO World Heritage site and one of Europe's largest Renaissance districts with narrow cobblestone streets, hidden traboules (passageways), and a vibrant atmosphere that captures the essence of historic Lyon.

location.description: Situated on the west bank of the Saône River at the foot of Fourvière Hill, Vieux Lyon spans three parishes: Saint-Jean (central), Saint-Paul (north), and Saint-Georges (south).

history.overview: Developed primarily in the 15th and 16th centuries when Lyon was a major European banking center and silk trading hub, Vieux Lyon features remarkable preservation of Renaissance architecture and urban planning.
history.significance: Represents Lyon's golden age of commerce and cultural exchange with Italy, evident in the Italian architectural influences throughout the quarter.
notable_events: Served as commercial and financial center in the Renaissance
Narrowly escaped demolition in the 1960s thanks to preservation efforts

practical_info.safety: Generally very safe, though pickpocketing can occur in crowded tourist areas. Exercise normal precautions.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Early morning or evening to avoid crowds; particularly magical at dusk when buildings are illuminated.
practical_info.walkability: Highly walkable but entirely pedestrianized with cobblestone streets that may challenge those with mobility issues.

attractions.name: Cathédrale Saint-Jean-Baptiste
attractions.description: 12th-15th century cathedral featuring an astronomical clock and remarkable stained glass windows.
attractions.appeal: Impressive medieval architecture and religious significance.

attractions.name: Traboules
attractions.description: Hidden corridors running between buildings and courtyards, originally used by silk workers.
attractions.appeal: Unique architectural feature offering a glimpse into Lyon's secretive past.

attractions.name: Musée Gadagne
attractions.description: Housed in a Renaissance mansion, featuring the Lyon History Museum and International Puppet Museum.
attractions.appeal: Comprehensive insight into Lyon's history with beautiful period rooms.

dining.name: Daniel et Denise
dining.known_for: Authentic bouchon cuisine by Meilleur Ouvrier de France chef Joseph Viola
dining.atmosphere: Classic bouchon with red-and-white checkered tablecloths

dining.name: Le Café du Soleil
dining.known_for: Hearty local specialties served in a historic setting

activities.name: Traboules Tour
activities.description: Explore the hidden passageways connecting buildings and courtyards throughout Vieux Lyon.

activities.name: Puppet Show at Théâtre Le Guignol
activities.description: Watch a traditional performance featuring Guignol, the famous puppet character created in Lyon.

stay_here_if: You want to immerse yourself in Lyon's Renaissance history
You enjoy atmospheric dining and active nightlife
You prefer historic surroundings with easy access to main attractions
avoid_if: You have mobility issues (cobblestones and stairs)
You're sensitive to noise (can be lively at night)
You prefer modern amenities and spacious accommodations
insider_tips: Many traboules are public but unmarked - look for small plaques or push door handles to check if they're open.
Visit on weekday mornings to have the most peaceful experience exploring the quarter.
The courtyard at 27 rue Saint-Jean has some of the most impressive Renaissance architecture but is often overlooked by tourists.

neighborhoods.name: La Croix-Rousse
neighborhoods.character: A bohemian, village-like district with a strong identity rooted in its silk-weaving history, now known for its artistic community, markets, and panoramic views of Lyon.

location.description: Located on a hill north of central Lyon, La Croix-Rousse is divided into the slopes (les pentes) and the plateau, rising above the Saône and Rhône rivers with sweeping city views.

history.overview: Formerly a working-class district dominated by silk workers (canuts) in the 19th century, whose workshops with high ceilings accommodated the Jacquard looms used in silk production.
history.significance: The heart of Lyon's silk industry and site of the canuts' revolts of the 1830s, important events in French labor history.
notable_events: Development of the Jacquard loom revolutionizing silk production
Resistance activity during World War II

transit: Metro C to Croix-Rousse or Hénon (plateau)
practical_info.safety: Very safe neighborhood popular with families and young professionals.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Tuesday-Sunday mornings for the market, afternoons for exploring the slopes.
practical_info.walkability: Highly walkable but prepare for substantial inclines on the slopes.

attractions.name: Marché de la Croix-Rousse
attractions.description: One of Lyon's best markets, stretching along Boulevard de la Croix-Rousse with over 100 vendors.
attractions.appeal: Exceptional local produce, regional specialties, and vibrant atmosphere.

attractions.name: Maison des Canuts
attractions.description: Museum dedicated to Lyon's silk-working tradition with demonstrations of Jacquard looms.
attractions.appeal: Insight into the technical innovation and social history of Lyon's silk industry.

attractions.name: Mur des Canuts
attractions.description: France's largest trompe l'oeil mural depicting life in La Croix-Rousse, updated periodically.
attractions.appeal: Remarkable artistic achievement and cultural landmark showing neighborhood evolution.

activities.name: Slopes Exploration
activities.description: Wander the steep streets, staircases, and traboules connecting Presqu'île to the plateau.

activities.name: Artisan Workshops
activities.description: Visit independent artisans continuing the creative tradition of the neighborhood.

stay_here_if: You want an authentic, non-touristy Lyon experience
You enjoy village atmosphere with city conveniences
You appreciate creative scenes and markets
avoid_if: You have mobility issues (many steep streets and stairs)
You want immediate access to major tourist attractions
insider_tips: The best views of Lyon are from the Gros Caillou landmark at the north end of the plateau.
Explore the 'pentes' (slopes) section for the most interesting independent shops and restaurants.
Visit the traboule at 9 place Colbert to see a six-story straight staircase, an architectural marvel.

neighborhoods.name: Presqu'île
neighborhoods.character: The elegant central district between Lyon's two rivers, featuring grand squares, 19th-century architecture, luxury shopping, and a sophisticated urban atmosphere.

location.description: A narrow peninsula between the Rhône and Saône rivers, forming Lyon's city center and main commercial district, stretching from Perrache in the south to the Croix-Rousse hill in the north.

history.overview: Transformed in the 19th century under Prefect Vaïsse (Lyon's Haussmann), who created wide boulevards and grand buildings, replacing medieval streets with the elegant district seen today.
history.significance: Represents Lyon's prosperity and importance as a major European city during the Industrial Revolution and Belle Époque periods.
notable_events: Construction of grand boulevards and squares
Development as Lyon's commercial and cultural center

transit: Metro lines A and D cross the peninsula
Tram T1 and T2 along the Rhône side
practical_info.safety: Very safe area with police presence, though standard city precautions apply, especially at night.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Weekdays for shopping, weekends for atmosphere, evenings for dining.
practical_info.walkability: Extremely walkable with wide sidewalks and pedestrianized areas.

attractions.name: Place Bellecour
attractions.description: One of Europe's largest open squares featuring a statue of Louis XIV and unobstructed views of Fourvière Hill.
attractions.appeal: The central point of Lyon and a major gathering place for events and celebrations.

attractions.name: Musée des Beaux-Arts
attractions.description: Housed in a former 17th-century abbey, one of France's largest and finest art collections outside Paris.
attractions.appeal: World-class collection spanning antiquity to modern art in a magnificent setting.

attractions.name: Place des Terreaux
attractions.description: Elegant square featuring Bartholdi's fountain, the Hôtel de Ville (City Hall), and the Fine Arts Museum.
attractions.appeal: Cultural heart of Lyon with beautiful architecture and vibrant cafe scene.

dining.name: Les Halles de Lyon Paul Bocuse
Brasserie Georges
dining.known_for: Classic French dishes in historic setting (est. 1836)

activities.name: Luxury Shopping
activities.description: Explore the boutiques along rue de la République and rue Édouard Herriot.

activities.name: Opera Performance
activities.description: Attend a performance at the striking contemporary Opéra National de Lyon in a renovated historic building.

stay_here_if: You want to be at the heart of Lyon's shopping and dining scene
You prefer central location with easy access to major attractions
You enjoy elegant surroundings and urban energy
avoid_if: You prefer to avoid tourist centers and higher prices
You want extensive green spaces nearby
insider_tips: The passages of the Cour des Loges between rue Saint-Jean and rue du Boeuf contain some of Lyon's best-preserved Renaissance architecture.
For the best view of Place Bellecour, visit the rooftop terrace of Galeries Lafayette department store.
Many restaurants close on Sundays and Mondays; plan accordingly or head to Rue Mercière, which has options open daily.

neighborhoods.name: Confluence
neighborhoods.character: Lyon's newest district showcasing bold contemporary architecture, sustainable urban planning, and cultural innovation at the meeting point of the Rhône and Saône rivers.

location.description: Located at the southernmost tip of the Presqu'île where the Rhône and Saône rivers meet, formerly an industrial area now transformed into a modern urban development.

history.overview: Historically an industrial and port area that fell into decline, Confluence has been the site of one of Europe's largest urban renewal projects since the early 2000s.
history.significance: Represents Lyon's commitment to sustainable development and architectural innovation for the 21st century.
notable_events: Opening of the Confluence Shopping Center in 2012
Inauguration of the Musée des Confluences in 2014

transit: Tram T1 runs through the district
Perrache train and metro station nearby
practical_info.safety: Very safe, modern area with good lighting and security features.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Daytime for architecture viewing, sunset for riverfront atmosphere.
practical_info.walkability: Extremely walkable with wide promenades and pedestrian-friendly design.

attractions.name: Musée des Confluences
attractions.description: A striking deconstructivist building housing natural history, anthropology, and society exhibitions.
attractions.appeal: Both architectural marvel and fascinating museum concept exploring human knowledge.

attractions.name: Place Nautique
attractions.description: Central water feature with pleasure boats and surrounded by restaurants and terraces.
attractions.appeal: Vibrant gathering place showcasing the district's connection to its rivers.

attractions.name: Architectural Walking Tour
attractions.description: Route passing distinctive buildings like the Orange Cube, Euronews headquarters, and sustainable housing projects.
attractions.appeal: Showcase of contemporary architectural innovation from renowned international architects.

dining.name: The Cousu
dining.known_for: Creative menu in Musée des Confluences

activities.name: Riverside Promenade
activities.description: Follow the landscaped pathways along both rivers to the actual confluence point.

activities.name: Confluence Shopping Center
activities.description: Eco-designed mall featuring retail, dining, and entertainment options.

stay_here_if: You appreciate contemporary architecture and design
You enjoy waterfront settings and don't mind being slightly removed from historic areas
avoid_if: You're primarily interested in historic architecture
You want to be in the heart of traditional Lyon
insider_tips: Visit La Sucrière, a former sugar warehouse converted to exhibition space that hosts many contemporary art events.
The best photography spot is from the tip of the peninsula where both rivers visibly meet.
Take the river shuttle (Vaporetto) from Vieux Lyon for a scenic approach to the district.

neighborhoods.name: Fourvière
neighborhoods.character: A sacred hill overlooking Lyon with Roman ruins, the iconic basilica, and breathtaking panoramic views, representing the spiritual heritage of the city.

location.description: Situated on the west bank of the Saône River, this steep hill rises dramatically above Vieux Lyon and offers commanding views of the entire city.

history.overview: Site of the original Roman settlement of Lugdunum founded in 43 BCE, later becoming a religious center with the construction of the Fourvière Basilica in the 19th century.
history.significance: Represents both the Roman origins of Lyon and its strong Catholic tradition, contrasting with Croix-Rousse ('the hill that works').
notable_events: Roman foundation of Lugdunum in 43 BCE
Construction of the Basilica (1872-1884) fulfilling a vow during the Franco-Prussian War
Annual Festival of Lights (December 8) centered around the illuminated Basilica

transit: Funicular from Vieux Lyon (quick and scenic)
practical_info.safety: Very safe area popular with tourists and pilgrims.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Morning for clearer views; avoid midday heat in summer; magical during Festival of Lights in December.
practical_info.walkability: The hilltop area is walkable but steep; the funicular is recommended for access.

attractions.name: Basilique Notre-Dame de Fourvière
attractions.description: 19th-century basilica with stunning mosaics, ornate interiors, and a distinctive silhouette visible throughout Lyon.
attractions.appeal: Religious significance, architectural splendor, and incredible city views from its esplanade.

attractions.name: Théâtres Romains de Fourvière
attractions.description: Well-preserved ancient Roman theater and odeon dating from 15 BCE, still used for summer performances.
attractions.appeal: Remarkable Roman ruins with excellent educational displays in an atmospheric setting.

attractions.name: Musée Gallo-Romain
attractions.description: Modern museum built into the hillside adjacent to the Roman theaters, housing exceptional Roman artifacts.
attractions.appeal: Comprehensive collection including mosaics, sculptures, and everyday items from Lugdunum.

dining.name: Les Terrasses de Fourvière
dining.known_for: Panoramic dining with views of Lyon

dining.name: L'Antiquaille
dining.known_for: Located in a historic hospital complex

activities.name: Nuits de Fourvière Festival
activities.description: Summer performance festival held in the Roman theaters featuring music, dance, theater, and circus arts.

activities.name: Fourvière Hill Gardens
activities.description: Peaceful gardens surrounding the basilica with walking paths and viewpoints.

stay_here_if: You value spectacular views and don't mind the climb
You're interested in Roman history and religious heritage
You prefer quiet surroundings away from urban bustle

activities.name: Festival Nuits Sonores
activities.description: Experience one of Europe's leading electronic music festivals, as Lyon transforms with cutting-edge performances, art installations, and events across historic and industrial venues.
activities.seasonal_notes: The festival typically runs for five days in May, attracting international artists and music enthusiasts to Lyon.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase passes well in advance as they sell out quickly. Consider day passes if you can't attend the full festival, and check the program for free city events.

activities.name: Croix-Rousse Market
activities.description: Visit the vibrant Marché de la Croix-Rousse in spring when the stalls overflow with fresh produce, spring flowers, and local specialties from the region.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring brings an abundance of local asparagus, strawberries, and early cherries to this authentic Lyonnais market.
activities.booking_tips: Visit Tuesday through Sunday mornings before 11am for the best selection. The boulevard location offers more food options than other city markets.

activities.name: Parc de la Tête d'Or in Bloom
activities.description: Explore Lyon's magnificent urban park when its famous rose garden, botanical collections, and flowering trees burst into spectacular spring color.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring is the optimal time to visit, especially May and June when the International Rose Garden showcases over 16,000 roses in full bloom.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. Enter through the golden gates for the most impressive first impression and rent a rowboat on the lake for a unique perspective.

activities.name: Cooking Workshop at Institut Paul Bocuse
activities.description: Learn spring cuisine techniques at a cooking workshop in the world-renowned culinary school founded by Lyon's legendary chef Paul Bocuse.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring workshops focus on fresh seasonal ingredients like spring vegetables, herbs, and traditional Lyonnaise spring dishes.
activities.booking_tips: Book at least one month in advance as classes fill quickly. Weekend workshops are particularly popular and often include market visits.

activities.name: Cycling Along Berges du Rhône
activities.description: Rent a bicycle and explore Lyon's transformed riverbanks along the Rhône, enjoying the spring sunshine, outdoor cafés, and urban beaches.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring offers perfect temperatures for cycling with blooming trees and plants along the 5km promenade.
activities.booking_tips: Use Vélo'v, Lyon's bike-sharing system, with stations throughout the city. Download the app for real-time availability and return locations.

activities.name: Les Nuits de Fourvière Preview Events
activities.description: Catch early season performances at the Roman theaters as the famous summer festival hosts preview events in the ancient amphitheaters overlooking Lyon.
activities.seasonal_notes: Late spring brings the first performances before the main festival begins, with pleasant evening temperatures and fewer crowds.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets online as soon as they're released, as even preview events sell out quickly. Bring layers as evenings can turn cool in the open-air venue.

activities.name: Beaujolais Vineyard Tours
activities.description: Visit the nearby Beaujolais wine region when the vineyards are lush with new growth and the countryside is painted with spring wildflowers.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring offers stunning vineyard landscapes with fewer tourists than harvest season, plus the opportunity to taste newly bottled vintages.
activities.booking_tips: Book a small-group tour with transportation from Lyon or take the regional train to Villefranche-sur-Saône and arrange vineyard visits from there.

activities.name: Printemps des Docks Design Fair
activities.description: Explore this spring design festival showcasing contemporary creators, artisans, and designers in the converted La Sucrière warehouse space in Confluence.
activities.seasonal_notes: This March/April event highlights home decor, fashion, gastronomy, and lifestyle trends in a stylish industrial setting.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online for a small discount and to avoid lines. The venue is easily accessible via tram from central Lyon.

activities.name: Urban Hike Through Traboules
activities.description: Discover Lyon's unique covered passageways (traboules) on a guided urban hike through Vieux Lyon and Croix-Rousse, learning about the city's silk-working history.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring offers pleasant temperatures for walking tours with fewer tourists than summer months.
activities.booking_tips: Book through the Tourist Office for the most comprehensive traboule access, as many of these passageways are within private buildings.

activities.name: Les Nuits de Fourvière Festival
activities.description: Experience Lyon's premier summer festival in the ancient Roman theaters atop Fourvière Hill, featuring diverse performances from international music acts to theater, dance, and circus arts.
activities.seasonal_notes: This festival runs from June through July in the spectacular setting of Lyon's 2,000-year-old Roman amphitheaters.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets months in advance for popular acts. Arrive early to enjoy the sunset views over Lyon before performances begin.

activities.name: Riverside Guinguettes
activities.description: Enjoy Lyon's summer pop-up riverside bars (guinguettes) along both the Rhône and Saône rivers, with food, drinks, music, and dancing under the stars.
activities.seasonal_notes: These seasonal open-air venues operate only in summer months, creating a festive atmosphere along Lyon's riverbanks.
activities.booking_tips: No reservations needed for most guinguettes, but arrive early evening to secure tables. La Terrasse de La Guillotière and La Commune are local favorites.

activities.name: Cruise the Saône and Rhône
activities.description: Take a river cruise through the heart of Lyon, viewing the city's architectural treasures from the water while learning about its 2,000-year history.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer evenings offer beautiful light for photography and pleasant temperatures for open-air deck viewing.
activities.booking_tips: Book dinner cruises at least a week in advance. For standard sightseeing cruises, the 'Lyon City Boat' offers regular departures from various docks.

activities.name: Cinema Under the Stars
activities.description: Experience outdoor film screenings in various Lyon locations, from the ancient Roman theaters to riverside venues and park settings.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer brings multiple open-air cinema events throughout the city, with both classic and contemporary films.
activities.booking_tips: Check the Institut Lumière (birthplace of cinema) program for their summer screenings. Bring a blanket and arrive early for popular films.

activities.name: Tout Le Monde Dehors Festival
activities.description: Participate in Lyon's summer-long outdoor festival featuring hundreds of free events throughout the city, from concerts and dance lessons to art installations and theatrical performances.
activities.seasonal_notes: From June to September, this festival animates parks, squares, and streets with daily activities for all ages.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required for most events. Pick up a program from the Tourist Office or download the app to plan your activities.

activities.name: Gourmet Food Tour of Les Halles
activities.description: Explore Lyon's culinary heart at Les Halles de Lyon Paul Bocuse on a guided tasting tour through this famous indoor food market.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer brings seasonal fruits and vegetables but also provides a cool escape from the heat while sampling Lyon's gastronomic treasures.
activities.booking_tips: Book small-group tours at least a week in advance. The market is closed Mondays, and vendors may take summer vacations in August.

activities.name: Vieux Lyon Renaissance Festival
activities.description: Step back in time at this historical festival in Lyon's Renaissance quarter, featuring period costumes, music, crafts, and food that celebrate the city's 16th-century golden age.
activities.seasonal_notes: This weekend festival in early summer transforms the old town with historical reenactments and authentic Renaissance atmosphere.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required, but guided tours of normally closed Renaissance courtyards during the festival should be reserved in advance.

activities.name: Kayaking on the Rhône
activities.description: Paddle through the heart of Lyon in a kayak or canoe, experiencing unique perspectives of the city's architecture and bridges from river level.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer provides ideal conditions with warm temperatures and generally calm river conditions, especially in the mornings.
activities.booking_tips: Rent equipment at Lyon Kayak near the Confluence district or join guided tours that include safety equipment and instruction.

activities.name: Festival Woodstower
activities.description: Enjoy this eco-responsible music festival at Grand Parc Miribel Jonage, combining outdoor concerts with lake swimming, nature activities, and sustainable initiatives.
activities.seasonal_notes: Taking place in late August, this festival offers a perfect end-of-summer celebration in a beautiful natural setting.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets in advance and consider camping options if attending multiple days. Public transportation is available but limited late at night.

activities.name: Lyon Street Food Festival
activities.description: Indulge in Lyon's largest food festival where renowned chefs, food trucks, and culinary artisans gather to showcase creative street food interpretations of both local and international cuisine.
activities.seasonal_notes: This September event highlights Lyon's gastronomic innovation in the atmospheric setting of former industrial spaces.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase entry tickets online before arriving and buy food tokens once inside. Go early to avoid the longest lines at popular vendors.

activities.name: Beaujolais Nouveau Release
activities.description: Participate in the celebrated release of Beaujolais Nouveau wine on the third Thursday of November, with tastings and festivities throughout Lyon's bouchons and wine bars.
activities.seasonal_notes: This famous French wine tradition is especially significant in Lyon given its proximity to the Beaujolais region.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve tables at popular bouchons weeks in advance for the release night. Many venues offer special menus paired with the new vintage.

activities.name: Mushroom Foraging in Monts du Lyonnais
activities.description: Join expert guides for a mushroom hunting expedition in the forests around Lyon, learning to identify edible varieties like cèpes, chanterelles, and trompettes de la mort.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn rains create ideal conditions for wild mushrooms in the forests and mountains surrounding Lyon.
activities.booking_tips: Book with certified guides who ensure safe foraging. Tours often include transportation from Lyon and a cooking demonstration with your findings.

activities.name: Festival Lumière
activities.description: Celebrate cinema in the city where it was born at this major film festival named after the Lumière brothers, featuring classic film screenings, restorations, and tributes to major directors and actors.
activities.seasonal_notes: This October festival brings film enthusiasts to Lyon with special screenings in historic venues including the original Lumière factory.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets for major events and retrospectives well in advance. The Lumière Award ceremony is a highlight attended by international film personalities.

activities.name: Salon du Chocolat Lyon
activities.description: Explore Lyon's chocolate fair featuring master chocolatiers, tastings, demonstrations, and chocolate fashion shows highlighting the art of fine chocolate.
activities.seasonal_notes: This November event coincides with the cooler autumn weather perfect for chocolate appreciation.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online for faster entry. Attend workshops and demonstrations by registering upon arrival at the venue.

activities.name: Contemporary Art Biennale
activities.description: Experience contemporary art installations throughout the city during Lyon's renowned Biennale of Contemporary Art, one of Europe's premier art events.
activities.seasonal_notes: This major art event takes place in odd-numbered years from September through January, transforming spaces throughout Lyon.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase the Biennale pass for access to all venues. Major installations at La Sucrière and the Museum of Contemporary Art are highlights.

activities.name: Autumn Colors in Parc de la Tête d'Or
activities.description: Witness the spectacular autumn transformation of Lyon's largest park as its 8,000+ trees display vibrant fall colors around the lake and botanical garden.
activities.seasonal_notes: Mid-October to early November typically offers the most dramatic color display before the leaves fall.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. The park is accessible from multiple gates with the Porte des Enfants du Rhône entrance convenient to the golden-hued tree collections.

activities.name: Cooking Class at Plum Lyon
activities.description: Learn to prepare autumn Lyonnaise specialties in an intimate cooking workshop in the Croix-Rousse district, focusing on seasonal market ingredients and traditional techniques.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn classes highlight game, mushrooms, and seasonal produce with dishes perfectly suited to cooler weather.
activities.booking_tips: Classes are held in a traditional Lyon apartment and limited to 6-8 participants, so book several weeks in advance.

activities.name: Lyon Whisky Festival
activities.description: Sample fine whiskies from around the world at this specialized festival, with masterclasses, food pairings, and opportunities to meet distillers.
activities.seasonal_notes: This autumn event complements Lyon's cooler weather with warming spirits and expert-led tastings.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets in advance as sessions often sell out. Consider special masterclass tickets for in-depth experiences with specific distilleries.

activities.name: Fête des Lumières (Festival of Lights)
activities.description: Experience Lyon's world-famous light festival when the entire city becomes an open-air gallery of spectacular light installations, video projections, and artistic illuminations.
activities.seasonal_notes: This four-day festival in early December transforms Lyon's monuments, rivers, parks and streets with stunning light art viewed by millions.
activities.booking_tips: Book accommodation months in advance. Follow suggested routes provided by the city to see the major installations and avoid the most crowded areas.

activities.name: Christmas Market at Place Carnot
activities.description: Wander through Lyon's traditional Christmas market with its wooden chalets offering festive foods, crafts, and seasonal specialties from across France and Europe.
activities.seasonal_notes: From late November through December, the market creates a magical winter atmosphere with lights, decorations, and seasonal treats.
activities.booking_tips: Visit on weekday evenings to avoid the weekend crowds. Try Lyonnaise holiday specialties like papillotes (chocolate wrapped in colorful paper) and vin chaud (mulled wine).

activities.name: Cooking Class at Institut Paul Bocuse
activities.description: Master the art of traditional Lyonnaise winter cuisine with a cooking workshop at the prestigious culinary school founded by Lyon's most celebrated chef.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter classes focus on hearty Lyonnaise classics like coq au vin, gratins, and festive desserts perfect for the season.
activities.booking_tips: Book at least a month in advance, especially for December classes. Gift certificates are available for a unique Lyon souvenir.

activities.name: Ice Skating at Place Bellecour
activities.description: Glide on ice in Lyon's largest public square with the seasonal ice rink set up during winter months, surrounded by festive decorations and winter charm.
activities.seasonal_notes: The rink typically operates from December through February, with special evening sessions featuring music and lights.
activities.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Skate rental is available on site, but bring your own thick socks. Weekday mornings are least crowded.

activities.name: Salon du Chocolat Lyon
activities.description: Indulge in Lyon's winter chocolate festival featuring master chocolatiers, tastings, demonstrations, and chocolate fashion shows highlighting the art of fine chocolate.
activities.seasonal_notes: This February event provides a sweet escape during the winter months with warming chocolate creations.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online for faster entry. Attend workshops and demonstrations by registering upon arrival at the venue.

activities.name: Museum Marathon
activities.description: Take advantage of Lyon's excellent museums during the winter months, using the Lyon City Card for access to the Museum of Fine Arts, Gallo-Roman Museum, and Confluence Museum.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter is ideal for museum exploration with special exhibitions and fewer tourists than summer months.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase the multi-day Lyon City Card for museum access plus public transportation. Many museums are closed on Tuesdays.

activities.name: Traditional Bouchon Experience
activities.description: Savor the ultimate Lyon winter comfort food experience in an authentic bouchon restaurant, enjoying hearty traditional specialties like pike quenelles, andouillette, and gratins.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter is the perfect season for Lyon's rich, warming traditional cuisine served in these historic restaurants.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve at certified 'Authentic Bouchons Lyonnais' like Daniel et Denise or Café des Fédérations. Lunch offers the best value with set menus.

activities.name: Opera or Ballet at Opéra de Lyon
activities.description: Attend a world-class opera or ballet performance at Lyon's stunning opera house, a renaissance exterior with a dramatically modern interior designed by Jean Nouvel.
activities.seasonal_notes: The winter season features classic productions and innovative performances in this internationally renowned venue.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets well in advance, especially for classic productions. Tours of the opera house are available during the day for those interested in the architecture.

activities.name: Wine Tasting in Vieux Lyon
activities.description: Escape the winter chill with a guided wine tasting in a historic cellar in Vieux Lyon, exploring the regions of Beaujolais, Côtes du Rhône, and Burgundy.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter evenings are perfect for discovering the rich red wines of the region in atmospheric historic settings.
activities.booking_tips: Book specialized tastings at places like La Cave des Voyageurs or Copper Lyon offering expert guidance through regional vintages.
